newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-AUSSIE GRAEME LLOYD DOING THE JOB.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-AUSSIE GRAEME LLOYD DOING THE JOB.

text.p: Suddenly, Graeme Lloyd, the first Australian to appear in a World Series, isn't looking like such a bad pick-up for the New York Yankees, after all.

The tall left-hander came over in a trade that had Yankees boss George Steinbrenner howling at his employee who made the trade, general manager Bob Watson, and Lloyd was booed on a regular basis in his ineffectual showings.
He was 0-2 with a startling 17.46 earned run average in the regular season for New York.
But Lloyd had his second successive effective appearance in the World Series Tuesday, throwing six key pitches in the Yankees' vital 5-2 win over the Atlanta Braves.
In the bottom of the eighth, with a man on, one out and the score 5-2, he defused two left-handed Atlanta power hitters, getting Fred McGriff to pop out and striking out Ryan Klesko.

"I'm just going out there and doing the job," Lloyd said. "Coming into the game in that kind of situation where it could have gotten out of hand, it was a confidence builder. I threw the pitches I wanted and I got the job done."
He outlined his strategy against McGriff: "He hits the ball to all fields. I try to throw the ball inside and outside and just keep him guessing what I'm going to throw."

Klesko had tried to bunt during his at-bat. "It puts a little bit of confidence in you that maybe he thinks he can't hit me. I decided to go right after him after that," said Lloyd. "With Klesko I just threw three sliders away."

Lloyd, who had a cortisone shot for his ailing pitching elbow just before joining the Yankees, came to New York with utility man Pat Listach, also injured, for outfielder Gerald Williams and right-handed reliever Bob Wickman.
Milwaukee later supplied lefty Ricky Bones to New York and took Listach back after the Yankees complained.
Watson has said Steinbrenner threatened to fire him if the trade is not reversed. But now the trade is looking pretty good for the Yankees.
"The general manager's pretty smart, isn't he?" joked field manager Joe Torre. "He made a helluva deal."

Lloyd, reflecting on his travails, said: "It seems a long way away from the World Series. With Milwaukee I had one of my best years, then when I was traded everything hit the fan. It was a tough time for me and I've gotten through that. I've looked at these playoffs and World Series like a clean slate."
The Yankees still have a grievance pending alleging the Brewers knew they were trading damaged goods in both cases.
